[[File:Being any Gender is a drag - World Pride London 2012 (7527764372).jpg|thumb|World Pride, London 2012]] '''Gender democracy''' is a [[normative]] idea related to [[gender mainstreaming]]. Its aim is to achieve democratic conditions between men and women within society as a whole, as well as specifically within companies, bureaucracies, and other organizations. Among other things, this is realized by means of [[gender training]]s that raise awareness of existing inequalities and develop methods to [[democratization|democratize]] relations between genders. The term gender democracy was first coined and developed by German [[sociology|sociologist]] Halina Bedkowski.<ref>[http://www.linksnet.de/de/artikel/18582 Jenseits von EMMA. Oder: Wie werden das Wissen und die Diskussionen des Feminismus], ''UTOPIE kreativ.'' No. 158, Dezember 2003, pp. 1144–1146.</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=oi9aL8iX8NoC&lpg=PA228&ots=vm6Apettti&dq=halina%20bendkowski&pg=PA228#v=onepage&q=halina%20bendkowski&f=false Jeffrey J. Anderson, Eric Langenbacher, From the Bonn to the Berlin Republic] {{ISBN|978-0-85745-221-4}} - see p. 228 (footnote 23)</ref>
== History of the term ==
[[File:GuentherZ 2012-06-05 0068 Wien06 Johanna-Dohnal-Platz Strassentafel enthuellt.jpg|thumb|Street sign marking Vienna's Johanna-Dohnal-Platz. In 1993, the term "Geschlechterdemokratie" (gender democracy) appeared on the title of a publication edited by Johanna Dohnal - a first]] According to Halina Bendkowski she developed the term and concept of gender democracy in the early 1990s during a "research trip to the US, which had been commissioned by Austria's Minister for Women, [[Johanna Dohal]], with the aim of identifying innovative projects against domestic violence."<ref>[http://www.linksnet.de/de/artikel/18582 Jenseits von EMMA. Oder: Wie werden das Wissen und die Diskussionen des Feminismus], ''UTOPIE kreativ.'' No. 158, Dezember 2003, pp. 1144–1146. The original German quotation reads: "...im Auftrag der österreichischen Frauenministerin Johanna Dohnal in den USA nach innovativen Projekten gegen häusliche Gewalt recherchierte"</ref> Subsequently, in 1993, the term appeared on the title of a publication edited by the [[Austrian Federal Ministry of Education and Women's Affairs]], "Test the West: Geschlechterdemokratie und Gewalt" (Test the West: Gender Democracy and Violence).<ref>Test the West: Geschlechterdemokratie und Gewalt (vol. 1 of "Gewalt gegen Frauen, Frauen gegen Gewalt"), ed. by Johanna Dohnal, Bundesministerin für Frauenangelegenheiten, Wien 1993</ref>
The pioneers of gender democracy refused to provide a fixed and static definition of the term. Bedkowski stated: "As soon as a term has been defined in a dictionary and recycled by other theorists, it will have lost most of its vitality. It is true, terms are alive - and this is especially true for terms that have been developed in the course of actual political conflicts."<ref>[http://www.linksnet.de/de/artikel/18582 Jenseits von EMMA. Oder: Wie werden das Wissen und die Diskussionen des Feminismus], ''UTOPIE kreativ.'' No. 158, Dezember 2003, pp. 1144–1146. The original German quotation reads: "Sobald Begriffe lexikalisch erfasst und theorierecycelt sind, haben sie ihr vitales Leben schon meist hinter sich. Ja, auch Begriffe leben, besonders die, die für und in politischen Realauseinandersetzungen gewonnen worden sind."</ref> Gunda Werner, who in 1999 outlined the basic tenets of gender democracy for the [[Heinrich Böll Foundation]], explained: "Gender democracy has no ready-made theoretical or practical precepts. It is an exploratory movement in search of new outlooks and models."<ref>[http://www.gwi-boell.de/sites/default/files/uploads/2014/04/zehn_thesen_von_gunda_werner_zu_geschlechterdemokratie_1999.pdf Gunda Werner: Geschlechterdemokratie 2000. Zehn Thesen zur Diskussion], PDF, October 1999The original German quotation reads: "Die Geschlechterdemokratie hat weder fertige praktische noch theoretische Konzepte. Sie ist eine Suchbewegung nach neuen Orientierungen und Modellen."</ref> Despite this, some of the fundamentals of gender democracy can be defined:
* Gender democracy is a normative precept, that is, an absolute moral and ethical [[axiom|postulate]]. * Gender democracy posits that the principles of democracy should not be limited to the sphere of politics but equally apply to the workplace and to personal life.<ref>[http://www.gwi-boell.de/en/2012/01/10/gender-democracy-goal-and-organisational-principle Gender democracy as a goal and an organisational principle], Gunda Werner Institute, January 2012. See the following statement: "Gender democracy must be realised on all levels of society: on a political, social and organisational level as well as on the level of everyday interactions. On a social and personal level this also means leaving behind structural patterns of hegemonic masculinity which continue to shape career paths and hierarchies in many companies and institutions."</ref>
== Goals and methods ==
Gender democracy aims to achieve the equal participation of women and men in politics, the corporate world, and in all parts of society by reforming and abolishing undemocratic structures and all forms of power that are based on oppression and violence. This approach is based on a broad definition of democracy - one that demands equal rights and opportunities for people in all their diversity. As there is a large number of [[gender identity|gender identities]], gender democracy rejects the male // female [[dichotomy]], arguing instead that each human being - female, male, or otherwise - must have the right and the ability to self-determine their lifestyles, type of relationships in ways that go beyond stereotypical notions and any type of [[essentialism]] about men and women.<ref>[http://www.gwi-boell.de/en/2012/01/10/gender-democracy-goal-and-organisational-principle Gender democracy as a goal and an organisational principle], Gunda Werner Institute, January 2012</ref>
Gender democracy investigates and questions structures and contents of democratic systems that were developed by men in order to transform them in ways that provide for gender equality. A key tool for implementing gender democracy are the so-called "gender traings" that aim to question traditional gender roles, analyze the social framework, and develop methods that provide for greater gender equality within organizations.
== Gender democracy within organizations ==
The following are some examples for organizations that have made gender democracy part of their institutional structures:
* The statutes of the [[Heinrich Böll Foundation]] define gender democracy as a "joint task"<ref>[https://www.boell.de/de/1989/index-309.html Satzung der Heinrich-Böll-Stiftung] § 2(3) states: "Ein besonderes Anliegen ist ihr die Verwirklichung von Geschlechterdemokratie als ein von Abhängigkeit und Dominanz freies Verhältnis der Geschlechter. Diese Gemeinschaftsaufgabe ist sowohl für die interne Zusammenarbeit als auch für die öffentliche Tätigkeit aller Bereiche ein maßgebliches Leitbild." ('A prime objective is to make gender democracy a reality, that is, relations between the genders that are free of dependency and dominance. This joint task guides all aspects of our organizational development as well as our public activities.')</ref> * The German trade union [[ver.di]] has defined the "realization of gender democracy" as one of its aims.<ref>[https://www.verdi.de/++file++5073a207deb5011af9001810/download/ver.di-Satzung.pdf Satzung ver.di - Vereinte Dienstleistungsgewerkschaft] PDF, September 2015. § 5.3(f) states: "Zur Erreichung dieser Ziele dienen insbesondere: Verwirklichung der Geschlechterdemokratie und der gleichberechtigten Teilhabe von Frauen und Männern in Betrieb, Wirtschaft, Gesellschaft und Politik, auch unter Anwendung des Gender Mainstreaming." ('To achieve these aims, gender democracy and the equitable participation of women and men in the workplace, the business world, society, and politics has to be put into practice, including through the use of gender mainstreaming.'</ref> * The statutes of the German political party [[The Left (Germany)|The Left]] contain a paragraph titled "gender democracy".<ref>[http://www.die-linke.de/partei/dokumente/bundessatzung-der-partei-die-linke/2-die-basis-der-partei/10-geschlechterdemokratie/ Bundessatzung der Partei Die Linke. § 10 Geschlechterdemokratie]</ref>

{{short description|Wikipedia's content on health and medicine topics}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} The online encyclopedia [[Wikipedia]] has, since the late 2000s, served as a popular source for health information for both laypersons and, in many cases, health care practitioners. Health-related articles on Wikipedia are popularly accessed as [[search engine result page|results]] from [[search engines]], which frequently deliver links to Wikipedia articles.<ref name="laurent">{{Cite journal | last1 = Laurent | first1 = M. R. | last2 = Vickers | first2 = T. J. | doi = 10.1197/jamia.M3059 | title = Seeking Health Information Online: Does Wikipedia Matter? | journal = Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association | volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 471–479 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19390105| pmc =2705249 }}</ref> Independent assessments have been made of the number and demographics of people who seek '''health information on Wikipedia''', the scope of health information on Wikipedia, and the quality of the information on Wikipedia.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Wikipedia: A Key Tool for Global Public Health Promotion|url = http://www.jmir.org/2011/1/e14/|journal = Journal of Medical Internet Research|date = 31 January 2011|pmc = 3221335|pmid = 21282098|volume = 13|issue = 1|doi = 10.2196/jmir.1589|first = James M|last = Heilman|first2 = Eckhard|last2 = Kemmann|first3 = Michael|last3 = Bonert|first4 = Anwesh|last4 = Chatterjee|first5 = Brent|last5 = Ragar|first6 = Graham M|last6 = Beards|first7 = David J|last7 = Iberri|first8 = Matthew|last8 = Harvey|first9 = Brendan|last9 = Thomas|page = e14}}</ref>
The [[English-language Wikipedia]] was estimated in 2014 to hold around 25,000 articles on health-related topics.<ref name="around half">{{cite web |title=Around half of Wikipedia's medical editors are experts |url=https://blog.wikimedia.org/2014/12/05/around-half-of-wikipedias-medical-editors-are-experts/ |work=Wikimedia Blog |first=Nusa |last=Faric |date=5 December 2014}}</ref> Across Wikipedia encyclopedias in all languages there were 155,000 health articles using 950,000 citations to sources and which collectively received 4.8 billion pageviews in 2013.<ref name="HeilmanWest2015">{{cite journal|last1=Heilman|first1=James M|last2=West|first2=Andrew G|title=Wikipedia and Medicine: Quantifying Readership, Editors, and the Significance of Natural Language|journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research|volume=17|issue=3|year=2015|pages=e62|issn=1438-8871|doi=10.2196/jmir.4069|pmid=25739399|pmc=4376174}}</ref> This amount of traffic makes Wikipedia one of the most consulted health resources in the world, or perhaps the most consulted resource.<ref name="HeilmanWest2015"/>
==Amount of health content== As of the end of 2013, the English Wikipedia had 29,072 medical articles, while across all language versions of Wikipedia, there were 155,805 medical articles.<ref name="HeilmanWest2015"/> As of March 2017, the English Wikipedia had 30,000 medical articles, while there were 164,000 medical articles in other languages.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Shafee |first1=Thomas |last2=Masukume |first2=Gwinyai |last3=Kipersztok |first3=Lisa |last4=Das |first4=Diptanshu |last5=Häggström |first5=Mikael |last6=Heilman |first6=James |date=November 2017 |title=Evolution of Wikipedia's medical content: past, present and future |url=http://jech.bmj.com/content/71/11/1122 |journal=Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health |volume=71 |issue=11 |pages=1122–1129 |doi=10.1136/jech-2016-208601|pmid=28847845 |pmc=5847101 }}</ref> As of 2017, there were about 6,000 anatomy articles on the English Wikipedia;<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ledger |first1=Thomas Stephen |date=September 2017 |title=Introduction to anatomy on Wikipedia |journal=Journal of Anatomy |volume=231 |issue=3 |pages=430–432 |doi=10.1111/joa.12640|pmid=28703298 }}</ref> these are not classified as "medical articles" in Wikipedia's categorization scheme and thus are not included in the 30,000 figure above.<ref name="HeilmanWest2015"/>
==Academic studies==
===Accuracy and usefulness=== A 2007 study examined a sample of Wikipedia pages about the most frequently performed surgical procedures in the United States, and found that 85.7% of them were appropriate for patients and that these articles had "a remarkably high level of internal validity".<ref name=jacs>{{cite journal|last1=Devgan|first1=Lara|last2=Powe|first2=Neil|last3=Blakey|first3=Brittony|last4=Makary|first4=Martin|title=Wiki-Surgery? Internal validity of Wikipedia as a medical and surgical reference|journal=Journal of the American College of Surgeons|date=September 2007|volume=205|issue=3|pages=S76–S77|doi=10.1016/j.jamcollsurg.2007.06.190}}</ref> However, the same study also raised concerns about Wikipedia's completeness, noting that only 62.9% of the articles examined were free of "critical omissions".<ref name=jacs/>
A 2008 study reported that drug information on Wikipedia "has a more narrow scope, is less complete, and has more errors of omission" than did such information on the traditionally edited online database [[Medscape Drug Reference]].<ref name="clauson">{{cite journal|last1=Clauson|first1=K. A|last2=Polen|first2=H. H|last3=Boulos|first3=M. N K.|last4=Dzenowagis|first4=J. H|title=Scope, Completeness, and Accuracy of Drug Information in Wikipedia|journal=Annals of Pharmacotherapy|date=18 November 2008|volume=42|issue=12|pages=1814–1821|doi=10.1345/aph.1L474|pmid=19017825}}</ref>
A 2011 assessment of 50 medical articles on Wikipedia found that 56% of the references cited on these pages could be considered reputable, and that each entry contained 29 reputable sources on average.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Haigh|first1=CA|title=Wikipedia as an evidence source for nursing and healthcare students.|journal=Nurse Education Today|date=February 2011|volume=31|issue=2|pages=135–9|doi=10.1016/j.nedt.2010.05.004|pmid=20646799}}</ref>
A 2011 study examined Wikipedia pages about five [[statin]]s, and concluded that these pages did not contain incorrect or misleading information, but that they were often missing information about drug interactions and contraindications to use.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kupferberg|first1=N|last2=Protus|first2=BM|title=Accuracy and completeness of drug information in Wikipedia: an assessment.|journal=Journal of the Medical Library Association : JMLA|date=October 2011|volume=99|issue=4|pages=310–3|pmid=22022226|doi=10.3163/1536-5050.99.4.010|pmc=3193353}}</ref>
Another 2011 study examining Wikipedia articles on the 20 most widely prescribed drugs found that seven of these articles did not have any references, and concluded that "Wikipedia does not provide consistently accurate, complete, and referenced medication information."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lavsa|first1=Stacey M.|last2=Corman|first2=Shelby L.|last3=Culley|first3=Colleen M.|last4=Pummer|first4=Tara L.|title=Reliability of Wikipedia as a medication information source for pharmacy students|journal=Currents in Pharmacy Teaching and Learning|date=April 2011|volume=3|issue=2|pages=154–158|doi=10.1016/j.cptl.2011.01.007}}</ref>
An assessment of Wikipedia articles in 2012 on [[dietary supplements]] found that Wikipedia articles were "frequently incomplete, of variable quality, and sometimes inconsistent with reputable sources of information on these products."<ref name="PhillipsLam2014">{{cite journal|last1=Phillips|first1=Jennifer|last2=Lam|first2=Connie|last3=Palmisano|first3=Lisa|title=Analysis of the accuracy and readability of herbal supplement information on Wikipedia|journal=Journal of the American Pharmacists Association|volume=54|issue=4|year=2014|pages=406–14|issn=1544-3191|doi=10.1331/JAPhA.2014.13181|pmid=25063262}}</ref>
A 2013 scoping review published in the ''[[Journal of Medical Internet Research]]'' summarized the existing evidence about the use of wikis, Wikipedia and other collaborative writing applications in health care and found that the available research publications were observational reports rather than the primary research studies which would be necessary to begin drawing conclusions.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Wikis and Collaborative Writing Applications in Health Care: A Scoping Review|url = http://www.jmir.org/2013/10/e210/|journal = [[Journal of Medical Internet Research]]|date = 8 October 2013|pmc = 3929050|pmid = 24103318|volume = 15|issue = 10|doi = 10.2196/jmir.2787|first = Patrick M|last = Archambault|first2 = Tom H van de|last2 = Belt|first3 = Francisco J Grajales|last3 = III|first4 = Marjan J|last4 = Faber|first5 = Craig E|last5 = Kuziemsky|first6 = Susie|last6 = Gagnon|first7 = Andrea|last7 = Bilodeau|first8 = Simon|last8 = Rioux|first9 = Willianne LDM|last9 = Nelen|page = e210}}</ref>
A 2014 study that examined 97 Wikipedia articles about [[complementary and alternative medicine]] (CAM) found that 4% of them had attained "Good article" status, and that CAM articles on Wikipedia tended to be significantly shorter than those about conventional therapies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Koo|first1=Malcolm|title=Complementary and Alternative Medicine on Wikipedia: Opportunities for Improvement|journal=Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine|date=2014|volume=2014|pages=1–4|doi=10.1155/2014/105186|pmid=24864148|pmc=4016830}}</ref>

A 2016 study found that drug information on Wikipedia was less accurate and complete than that on the medical reference site [[Micromedex]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Reilly|first1=Timothy|last2=Jackson|first2=William|last3=Berger|first3=Victoria|last4=Candelario|first4=Danielle|title=Accuracy and completeness of drug information in Wikipedia medication monographs|journal=Journal of the American Pharmacists Association|date=November 2016|doi=10.1016/j.japh.2016.10.007|pmid=27866956|volume=57|issue=2|pages=193–196.e1}}</ref>
A 2017 study compared the accuracy of Wikipedia articles about the 33 most popular medications with medication guides to the accuracy of their medication guides. The study found that the Wikipedia articles were generally less accurate than were the corresponding medication guides.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Candelario|first1=Danielle M.|last2=Vazquez|first2=Victoria|last3=Jackson|first3=William|last4=Reilly|first4=Timothy|title=Completeness, accuracy, and readability of Wikipedia as a reference for patient medication information|journal=Journal of the American Pharmacists Association|date=January 2017|doi=10.1016/j.japh.2016.12.063|pmid=28139458|lay-url=http://www.pharmacist.com/article/japha-study-shows-incomplete-and-inaccurate-patient-drug-information-wikipedia|lay-date=2017-01-30|lay-source=Pharmacist.com|volume=57|issue=2|pages=197–200.e1}}</ref>
===Readability===
A 2013 review of [[nephrology]] content on Wikipedia found it to be "a comprehensive and fairly reliable medical resource for nephrology patients that is written at a college reading level".<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Thomas | first1 = G. R. | last2 = Eng | first2 = L. | last3 = De Wolff | first3 = J. F. | last4 = Grover | first4 = S. C. | title = An Evaluation of Wikipedia as a Resource for Patient Education in Nephrology | doi = 10.1111/sdi.12059 | journal = Seminars in Dialysis | pages = 159–63 | year = 2013 | pmid = 23432369 | pmc = | volume=26 | issue=2}}</ref>
A 2014 study found that Wikipedia's article on [[Parkinson's disease]] had a [[Flesch–Kincaid readability tests#Flesch reading ease|Flesch reading ease]] score of 30.31, meaning that it was difficult to read.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brigo|first1=F|last2=Erro|first2=R|title=The readability of the English Wikipedia article on Parkinson's disease|journal=Neurological Sciences|volume=36|issue=6|pages=1045–6|date=18 January 2015|pmid=25596713|doi=10.1007/s10072-015-2077-5}}</ref>
The readability of Wikipedia's articles on [[epilepsy]] was evaluated and found to be low, indicating that they were difficult to read.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brigo|first1=F|last2=Otte|first2=WM|last3=Igwe|first3=SC|last4=Tezzon|first4=F|last5=Nardone|first5=R|title=Clearly written, easily comprehended? The readability of websites providing information on epilepsy.|journal=Epilepsy & Behavior|date=16 January 2015|volume=44C|pages=35–39|pmid=25601720|doi=10.1016/j.yebeh.2014.12.029}}</ref> Another study found that Wikipedia's information about neurological diseases was significantly more difficult to read than the information in the [[American Academy of Neurology]]'s patient brochures, the [[Mayo Clinic]]'s website, or [[MedlinePlus]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Punia|first1=Vineet|last2=Dagar|first2=Anjali|last3=Agarwal|first3=Nitin|last4=He|first4=Wenzhuan|last5=Hillen|first5=Machteld|title=Comparison of neurological healthcare oriented educational resources for patients on the internet|journal=Journal of Clinical Neuroscience|date=December 2014|volume=21|issue=12|pages=2179–2183|doi=10.1016/j.jocn.2014.05.043|pmid=25194822}}</ref> Another 2015 study, this one authored by [[Samy Azer]], reported that Wikipedia should not be used to learn about concepts related to pulmonology students.<ref name="Azer2015">{{cite journal|last1=Azer|first1=Samy A.|title=Is Wikipedia a reliable learning resource for medical students? Evaluating respiratory topics|journal=Advances in Physiology Education|volume=39|issue=1|year=2015|pages=5–14±|issn=1043-4046|doi=10.1152/advan.00110.2014|pmid=25727464}}</ref> Another 2015 study by Azer found that Wikipedia entries about [[cardiovascular diseases]] were "not aimed at a medical audience" and were mainly inaccurate due to errors of omission.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Azer|first1=SA|last2=AlSwaidan|first2=NM|last3=Alshwairikh|first3=LA|last4=AlShammari|first4=JM|title=Accuracy and readability of cardiovascular entries on Wikipedia: are they reliable learning resources for medical students?|journal=BMJ Open|date=6 October 2015|volume=5|issue=10|pages=e008187|doi= 10.1136/bmjopen-2015-008187|pmid=26443650|pmc=4606442}} {{open access}}</ref>
A 2016 study found that Wikipedia information about common [[internal medicine]] diagnoses was written at a higher grade level than any of the four other sites studied (NIH, WebMD, Mayo Clinic, and "diagnosis-specific websites").<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hutchinson|first1=N|last2=Baird|first2=GL|last3=Garg|first3=M|title=Examining the reading level of Internet medical information for common Internal Medicine diagnoses|journal=The American Journal of Medicine|date=29 January 2016|pmid=26829438|doi=10.1016/j.amjmed.2016.01.008|volume=129|issue=6|pages=637–9}}</ref> In contrast, another study published the same year found that medical students reading about three unstudied diseases on [[AccessMedicine]] and Wikipedia experienced less mental effort than did readers of the same diseases on [[UpToDate]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Saparova|first1=D|last2=Nolan|first2=NS|title=Evaluating the appropriateness of electronic information resources for learning.|journal=Journal of the Medical Library Association : JMLA|date=January 2016|volume=104|issue=1|pages=24–32|pmid=26807049|doi=10.3163/1536-5050.104.1.004|pmc=4722638}}</ref>
A 2017 study evaluating 134 Wikipedia articles on [[autoimmune disease]]s found that they were very difficult to read and required at least a university graduate reading level. The study's authors were concerned by Wikipedia's low readability, as people with autoimmune disorders often use Wikipedia to research their condition.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Watad |first1=Abdulla |last2=Bragazzi |first2=Nicola Luigi |last3=Brigo |first3=Francesco |last4=Sharif |first4=Kassem |last5=Amital |first5=Howard |last6=McGonagle |first6=Dennis |last7=Shoenfeld |first7=Yehuda |last8=Adawi |first8=Mohammad |date=2017 |title=Readability of Wikipedia Pages on Autoimmune Disorders: Systematic Quantitative Assessment |url=http://www.jmir.org/2017/7/e260/ |journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research (JMIR) |volume=19 |issue=7 |pages=e260 |doi=10.2196/jmir.8225|pmid=28720555 |pmc=5539385 }}</ref>
A 2018 study evaluating 55 Wikipedia articles on [[neurosurgery|neurosurgical]] topics found that they were significantly more difficult to read than the [[American Association of Neurological Surgeons]]'s patient information articles, although both Wikipedia's articles and the AANS articles required a college reading level.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Modiria |first1=Omen |last2=Guhab |first2=Daipayan |last3=Alotaibib |first3=Naif M. |last4=Ibrahim |first4=George M. |last5=Lipsmanb |first5=Nor |last6=Fallahc |first6=Aria |date=2018 |title=Readability and quality of wikipedia pages on neurosurgical topics |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0303846718300271?via%3Dihub |journal=Clinical Neurology and Neurosurgery |volume=166 |pages=66–70 |doi=10.1016/j.clineuro.2018.01.021|pmid=29408776 }}</ref>
==Other views== Wikipedia co-founder [[Jimmy Wales]] has said that lack of health information increases [[List of preventable causes of death|preventable deaths]] in [[emerging markets]] and that health information from Wikipedia can improve community health.<ref name="Grut 2014">{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/wikipedia-founder-jimmy-wales-free-wiki-could-save-thousands-of-lives-9773559.html |title=Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales: 'Free Wiki could save thousands of lives' |first=Oscar |last=Williams-Grut |work=[[The Independent]] |date=3 October 2014 |publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref> Wales presented the [[Wikipedia Zero]] project as a channel for delivering health information into places where people have difficulty accessing online information.<ref name="Grut 2014"/>
As a result of public interest in the 2014 [[Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa]], Wikipedia became a popular source of information on [[Ebola]].<ref name="25October2014 NYT">{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/27/business/media/wikipedia-is-emerging-as-trusted-internet-source-for-information-on-ebola-.html? |title=Wikipedia Emerges as Trusted Internet Source for Ebola Information |first=Noam |last=Cohen |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=26 October 2014 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref> Doctors who were Wikipedia contributors said that Wikipedia's quality made it useful.<ref name="25October2014 NYT"/>
===Alternative medicine===
People who promote [[alternative medicine]] have complained that Wikipedia negatively portrays [[holistic health]] treatments including [[energy medicine]], [[Emotional Freedom Techniques]], [[Thought Field Therapy]] and [[Tapas Acupressure Technique]].<ref name="Time March 2014">{{cite web |url= http://time.com/36938/wikipedia-founder-sticks-it-to-lunatic-holistic-healers/ |title=Wikipedia Founder Sticks It To 'Lunatic' Holistic Healers |first=Alexandra |last=Sifferlin |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=25 March 2014 |accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> In response, Wales has stated, "If you can get your work published in respectable scientific journals – that is to say, if you can produce evidence through replicable scientific experiments, then Wikipedia will cover it appropriately."<ref name="Time March 2014"/><ref>Hay Newman, Lily (27 March 2014) [http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2014/03/27/jimmy_wales_denies_petition_from_advocates_of_holistic_healing_about_wikipedia.html Jimmy Wales Gets Real, and Sassy, About Wikipedia's Holistic Healing Coverage], [[Slate (magazine)]] Retrieved 23 November 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.energypsych.org/?wikipediastatement ACEP's Position Statement on Wikipedia] energypsych.org Retrieved 23 November 2014</ref> Similar concerns have been raised regarding its coverage of [[homeopathy]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/dana-ullman/dysfunction-at-wikipedia-_b_5924226.html|title = Dysfunction at Wikipedia on Homeopathic Medicine|last = Ullman|first = Dana|date = 10 October 2014|work = [[The Huffington Post]]|access-date = 23 November 2014|via = |author-link = Dana Ullman}}</ref>
Wikipedia policy for articles that "could reasonably be perceived as relating to human health" comes under the policy for [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources (medicine-related articles)|medicine-related articles]] which is [[science]]-based.
==Usage== The majority of people in the United States use the internet as a source of health information.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Fox, S.|author2= Jones, S.|title=The social life of health information|location=Washington, DC: Pew Internet and American Life Project (cited 6 October 2010)|date= 11 June 2009 |url=http://www.pewinternet.org/Reports/2009/8-The-Social-Life-of-Health-Information.aspx}}</ref> One 2013 study suggested that 22% of healthcare searches online direct users to Wikipedia.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.makovsky.com/insights/articles/25-insights/articles/article/229-as-the-web-goes-mobile-healthcare-stands-still |title=Online Health Research Eclipsing Patient-Doctor Conversations – Makovsky |author=Makovsky Health |work=makovsky.com |date=9 September 2013 |accessdate=2 October 2013}}</ref>
Wikipedia was described in 2014 as "the leading single source of healthcare information for patients and healthcare professionals".<ref>Note – sketchy link requires registration. {{cite |title=America's future doctors are starting their careers by saving Wikipedia |first=Rachel |last=Feltman |work=[[Quartz (publication)|qz.com]] |date=28 January 2014 |accessdate=5 February 2014}} ===General public===
A 2015 study compared the popularity of Wikipedia's articles on ten of the most common neurological disorders over a 90-day period from April 2014 to July 2014; it found that there was no relationship between the incidence or prevalence of a neurological disorder and the number of page views it received. For example, Wikipedia's article on [[multiple sclerosis]] was far more popular than its articles on more common disorders like [[migraine]], [[epilepsy]], or [[stroke]]. The authors theorized that this might be due to the increasing prevalence of [[MRI scans]], which has led to an increase in incidental findings of [[white matter lesion]]s. Although most of these lesions have nothing to do with multiple sclerosis, they may lead patients, relatives, and even physicians to perform Internet searches on "multiple sclerosis", which may lead them to the Wikipedia article.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Brigo |first1=Francesco |last2=Igwe |first2=Stanley C. |last3=Nardone |first3=Raffaele |last4=Lochner |first4=Piergiorgio |last5=Tezzon |first5=Freudiano |last6=Otte |first6=Willem M. |date=2015 |title=Wikipedia and neurological disorders |url=https://www.jocn-journal.com/article/S0967-5868(15)00099-5/fulltext |journal=Journal of Clinical Neuroscience |volume=22 |issue=7 |pages=1170–1172 |doi=10.1016/j.jocn.2015.02.006|pmid=25890773 }}</ref>
===Medical students=== Wikipedia's health information has been described as "transforming how our next doctors learn medicine".<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/columns/2013/11/18/wikipedia-role-medical-education-brings-awesome-promise-and-few-risks/iasrC5cWfCPhWkF9R0mZ4L/story.html |title=Wikipedia's role in medical education brings awesome promise — and a few risks |first=Nathaniel P. |last=Morris |work=bostonglobe.com |date=18 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013}}</ref> Various commentators in health education have said that Wikipedia is popular among medical students.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Teunis|first1=Teun|title=The Wikipedia Guide to Medicine Could the Online Encyclopaedia Provide the Basis for a New Medical School Curriculum?|journal=Student BMJ|date=March 2013|volume=21|pages=16–17|doi=10.1136/sbmj.f1091|url=http://student.bmj.com/student/view-article.html?id=sbmj.f1091|doi-broken-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
A 2013 study done at a single medical school showed that 97% of students used Wikipedia to study medicine, with the most common reasons being ease of access and ease of understanding. There was no relationship between a student's year in medical school and his or her use of Wikipedia, but students further along in medical school were less likely to use Wikipedia as their first resource, only resource, or most common resource; they were also more likely to perceive Wikipedia as unreliable.<ref name="AllahwalaNadkarni2013">{{cite journal|last1=Allahwala|first1=Usaid K.|last2=Nadkarni|first2=Aniket|last3=Sebaratnam|first3=Deshan F.|title=Wikipedia use amongst medical students – New insights into the digital revolution|journal=Medical Teacher|volume=35|issue=4|year=2013|pages=337|issn=0142-159X|doi=10.3109/0142159X.2012.737064|pmid=23137251}}</ref>
In 2013, [[UCSF School of Medicine]] began to offer fourth-year medical students a month-long elective centered around improving Wikipedia's health-related articles. Between 2013 and 2015, 43 students took part in the course and chose a single health-related article to work on. A study of their contributions by UCSF faculty found that the students expanded their articles, added higher-quality sources, removed lower-quality sources, and improved readability. The study's authors argued that medical schools should encourage students to contribute to Wikipedia, both to improve the quality of its content and to enable students to become better health care educators.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Azzam |first1=A |last2=Bresler |first2=D |last3=Leon |first3=A |last4=Maggio |first4=L |last5=Whitaker |first5=E |last6=Heilman |first6=J |last7=Orlowitz |first7=J |last8=Swisher |first8=V |last9=Rasberry |first9=L |last10=Otoide |first10=K |last11=Trotter |first11=F |last12=Ross |first12=W |last13=McCue |first13=JD |title=Why Medical Schools Should Embrace Wikipedia: Final-Year Medical Student Contributions to Wikipedia Articles for Academic Credit at One School. |journal=Academic Medicine |date=February 2017 |volume=92 |issue=2 |pages=194–200 |doi=10.1097/ACM.0000000000001381 |pmid=27627633 |pmc=5265689}}</ref>
A 2015 study of five European medical schools found that students who used Wikipedia for general information were more likely to use it to look up medical information. 16% of students used Wikipedia often for general information, 60% sometimes, and 24% rarely. 12% of students used Wikipedia often for medical information, 55% sometimes, and 33% rarely. Almost all of the students (97%) found inaccurate information on Wikipedia at least once, but less than 20% of them corrected it.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Herbert |first1=Verena G. |last2=Frings |first2=Andreas |last3=Rehatschek |first3=Herwig |last4=Richard |first4=Gilbert |last5=Leithner |first5=Andreas |date=2015 |title=Wikipedia – challenges and new horizons in enhancing medical education |journal=BMC Medical Education |volume=15 |issue=32 |pages= 32|doi=10.1186/s12909-015-0309-2|pmid=25879421 |pmc=4384304 }}</ref>
A 2017 study of online resource use by first-year medical students at [[Melbourne Medical School]] found that they used the school's online learning platform most often (daily) and used Google and Wikipedia slightly less often (approximately daily). The students considered the learning platform to be most useful, followed by Google and Wikipedia, which they considered slightly less useful than the learning platform but significantly more useful than Facebook or [[Google Scholar]]. They also considered the learning platform to be the most reliable and considered Google and Wikipedia to be significantly less reliable, although they frequently used both websites as a starting point for finding information.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Judd |first1=Terry |last2=Elliott |first2=Kristine |date=2017 |title=Selection and Use of Online Learning Resources by First-Year Medical Students: Cross-Sectional Study |url=http://mededu.jmir.org/2017/2/e17/ |journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research I |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=e17 |doi=10.2196/mededu.7382|pmid=28970187 |pmc=5643842 }}</ref>
A 2018 study of resources used by medical students during their general surgery [[Clinical clerkship|clerkship]] at the [[University of Florida College of Medicine]] found that review books were the most commonly used type of study resource, followed by the Internet. Wikipedia was the third-most commonly used resource and the most commonly used Internet resource. The study found no correlation between the type of resource used and students' performance on the NBME surgery subject exam.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Taylor |first1=Janice A. |last2=Shaw |first2=Christiana M. |last3=Tan |first3=Sanda A. |last4=Falcone |first4=John L. |date=2017 |title=Are the kids alright? Review books and the internet as the most common study resources for the general surgery clerkship |journal=The American Journal of Surgery |volume=215 |issue=1 |pages=191–195 |doi=10.1016/j.amjsurg.2017.01.036|pmid=28237045 }}</ref>
===Residents=== A 2009 study of Internet use by 35 [[junior doctors]] in the United Kingdom found that 80% of them used Google and 70% of them used Wikipedia to look up medical information at least once a week, while only 30% used [[PubMed]]. Google and Wikipedia were primarily used for background reading, while PubMed and other "best evidence" websites were used to answer specific questions for clinical decision-making.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hughes |first1=Benjamin |last2=Joshi |first2=Indra |last3=Lemonde |first3=Hugh |last4=Wareham |first4=Jonathan |date=October 2009 |title=Junior physician's use of Web 2.0 for information seeking and medical education: A qualitative study |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1386505609000756?via%3Dihub |journal=International Journal of Medical Informatics |volume=78 |issue=10 |pages=645–655 |doi=10.1016/j.ijmedinf.2009.04.008|pmid=19501017 }}</ref>
A 2015 survey of psychiatry residents at [[Harvard Medical School]] found that they used online resources twice as often as they used printed resources. The three most commonly used resources were UpToDate, [[PubMed]], and Wikipedia. UpToDate was the most used resource and was considered to be the most trustworthy, while PubMed was the second most used resource and was highly rated as a source of personal learning. Wikipedia was the third most used resource and received the highest ranking for ease of use; however, it was considered the least trustworthy.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Torous |first1=John |last2=Franzen |first2=Jamie |last3=O’Connor |first3=Ryan |last4=Mathew |first4=Ian |last5=Keshavan |first5=Matcher |last6=Kitts |first6=Robert |last7=Boland |first7=Robert |date=2015 |title=Psychiatry Residents' Use of Educational Websites: A Pilot Survey Study |journal=Academic Psychiatry |volume=39 |issue=6 |pages=630–633 |doi=10.1007/s40596-015-0335-8|pmid=26077007 }}</ref>
===Physicians and other health professionals=== A 2014 study of 259 health professionals in Spain found that while 53% of them used the [[Spanish Wikipedia]] to look up medical information during work, only 3% of them considered it reliable and only 16% recommended it to their patients. Only 16% had ever edited a Wikipedia article; the most common reasons for not doing were that they did not consider themselves an expert (51%), they preferred to blog or publish peer-reviewed articles (21%), and they were concerned that someone would undo any contributions they made (17%).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Santillán |first1=Azucena |last2=Máñez |first2=Miguel Ángel |last3=Meijome |first3=Xose Manuel |date=2014 |title=Uso de Wikipedia por los profesionales de la salud |trans-title=Use of Wikipedia by health professionals |url=http://www.gacetasanitaria.org/es/uso-wikipedia-por-los-profesionales/articulo/S0213911114001964/ |language=Spanish |journal=Gaceta Sanitaria |volume=28 |issue=6 |pages=522 |doi=10.1016/j.gaceta.2014.04.014|pmid=25087118 }}</ref>
===Academic citations=== Wikipedia has been inappropriately cited as an authoritative source in many health science journals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bould|first=M. D.|author2=Hladkowicz, E. S. |author3=Pigford, A.-A. E. |author4=Ufholz, L.-A. |author5=Postonogova, T. |author6=Shin, E. |author7= Boet, S. |title=References that anyone can edit: review of Wikipedia citations in peer reviewed health science literature|journal=[[BMJ]]|date=6 March 2014|volume=348|issue=mar05 4|pages=g1585|doi=10.1136/bmj.g1585|pmid=24603564|pmc=3944683}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/03/12/its-against-all-principles-of-scientific-reporting-thousands-of-medical-papers-cite-wikipedia-study-says/ |title='It's against all principles of scientific reporting': Thousands of medical papers cite Wikipedia, study says |first=Tom |last=Blackwell |work=[[National Post]] |date=12 March 2014 |accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref>
===Impact on psychological tests=== In 2009 a doctor and Wikipedia editor, [[James Heilman]], incorporated [[public domain]] images of the [[Rorschach test]] into Wikipedia.<ref name="rorschach"> *{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/29/technology/internet/29inkblot.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |title=Has Wikipedia Created a Rorschach Cheat Sheet? Analyze That - NYTimes.com |first=Noam |last=Cohen |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=28 July 2009 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=2 October 2013}} *{{cite web |url= http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-skeptical-psychologist/200908/the-rorschach-wikipedia-kerfuffle-continues |title=The Rorschach-Wikipedia Kerfuffle Continues |first=Scott |last=Lilienfeld |work=[[Psychology Today]] |date=3 August 2009 |accessdate=2 October 2013}} *{{Cite news |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/rorschach-and-wikipedia-the-battle-of-the-inkblots/article4280876/ |title=Rorschach and Wikipedia: The battle of the inkblots – The Globe and Mail |first=Patrick |last=White |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=29 July 2009 |accessdate=2 October 2013}} *{{Cite journal | last1 = Schultz | first1 = D. S. | last2 = Brabender | first2 = V. M. | doi = 10.1080/00223891.2012.725438 | title = More Challenges Since Wikipedia: The Effects of Exposure to Internet Information About the Rorschach on Selected Comprehensive System Variables | journal = Journal of Personality Assessment | volume = 95 | issue = 2 | pages = 149–158 | year = 2013 | pmid = 23030722 | pmc = }}</ref> Psychologists complained that the increased public exposure to these tests devalued their clinical utility, and that public health was harmed as a result.<ref name="rorschach"/>
==Nature of contributors== A 2014 interview study found that around half of the editors of health-related content on the English-language Wikipedia are health care professionals, while the other half includes some medical students.<ref name="around half" /> An author of this study wrote that this provides "reassurance about the reliability of the website".<ref name="around half" /> The study also found that the "core editor community", who actively monitor and edit most health-related articles on the English-language Wikipedia, numbered around 300 people.<ref name="FaričPotts2014">{{cite journal|last1=Farič|first1=Nuša|last2=Potts|first2=Henry WW|title=Motivations for Contributing to Health-Related Articles on Wikipedia: An Interview Study|journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research|volume=16|issue=12|year=2014|pages=e260|issn=1438-8871|doi=10.2196/jmir.3569|pmid=25498308|pmc=4275502}}</ref> The study found that people who contribute on these topics do so for a variety of reasons, including a desire to better learn the subjects themselves, and a sense of both responsibility and enjoyment in improving others' access to health information.<ref name="FaričPotts2014"/>
A 2016 study found that Wikipedia editors who contributed to articles on [[designer drug]]s were most likely to also contribute to articles on illegal drugs and pharmaceutical drugs, implying that they have a background in pharmacology. They were also more likely to contribute to articles on neurological disorders, psychiatric disorders, other diseases, and cell biology; they were least likely to edit articles about popular culture topics or history.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Dijkstra |first1=Louis J. |last2=Krieg |first2=Lisa J. |date=2016 |title=From MDMA to Lady Gaga: Expertise and contribution behavior of editing communities on Wikipedia |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1877050916326801 |journal=Procedia Computer Science |volume=1 |pages=96–106 |doi=10.1016/j.procs.2016.11.013|bibcode=2010ProCS...1.1119G |arxiv=1005.5384 }}</ref>
==Traffic statistics in health monitoring== Just as [[Google Flu Trends]] was able to correlate searches for flu to local [[outbreaks]] of [[flu]], page views of Wikipedia articles on flu-related topics have been found to increase in populations experiencing the spread of flu,<ref>{{cite journal|last=McIver|first=David J.|author2=Brownstein, John S. |author3=Salathé, Marcel |title=Wikipedia Usage Estimates Prevalence of Influenza-Like Illness in the United States in Near Real-Time|journal=[[PLoS Computational Biology]]|date=17 April 2014|volume=10|issue=4|pages=e1003581|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003581|pmid=24743682 |pmc=3990502|bibcode=2014PLSCB..10E3581M}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.technologyreview.com/view/532246/how-wikipedia-data-is-revolutionizing-flu-forecasting/ |title=How Wikipedia Data Is Revolutionizing Flu Forecasting |author=none listed |work=[[MIT Technology Review]] |date=3 November 2014 |accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref> and of other diseases such as [[dengue fever]] and [[tuberculosis]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Generous|first1=Nicholas|last2=Fairchild|first2=Geoffrey|last3=Deshpande|first3=Alina|last4=Del Valle|first4=Sara Y.|last5=Priedhorsky|first5=Reid|last6=Salathé|first6=Marcel|title=Global Disease Monitoring and Forecasting with Wikipedia|journal=PLoS Computational Biology|date=13 November 2014|volume=10|issue=11|pages=e1003892|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003892|pmid=25392913|pmc=4231164|bibcode=2014PLSCB..10E3892G|arxiv=1405.3612}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/health-30021644 | title=Wikipedia 'foresees virus outbreaks' | newspaper=BBC News | date=13 November 2014 | accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref>
==Projects to improve health information on Wikipedia== In 2009 the [[National Institutes of Health]] attempted a pilot project for integrating health information into Wikipedia.<ref> *{{cite web |url= https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2009/07/wikipedia-training-scientists-on-wiki-culture/ |title=Wikipedia Teaches NIH Scientists Wiki Culture – Wired Science |first=Alexis |last=Madrigal |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=21 July 2009 |accessdate=2 October 2013}} *{{cite web |url= http://nihrecord.od.nih.gov/newsletters/2009/09_04_2009/story2.htm |title=NIH, Wikipedia Join Forces to Improve Online Health Info |first=Carla |last=Garnett |work=[[NIH Record]] |date=4 September 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2012}}</ref> In 2011, it was reported that [[Cancer Research UK]] had started a program whereby some of its staff would edit Wikipedia's cancer-related articles.<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/health-12887075 | title=Cancer charity 'tidies' Wikipedia | newspaper=BBC News | date=4 April 2011 | accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref>
The [[University of California, San Francisco]] has a program for encouraging students to contribute health content to Wikipedia.<ref> *{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/30/business/media/editing-wikipedia-pages-for-med-school-credit.html |title=Editing Wikipedia Pages for Med School Credit - NYTimes.com |first=Noam |last=Cohen |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=29 September 2013 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=1 October 2013}} *{{cite web |url= http://www.ucsf.edu/news/2013/09/109201/ucsf-first-us-medical-school-offer-credit-wikipedia-articles |title=UCSF First U.S. Medical School to Offer Credit For Wikipedia Articles |first=Juliana |last=Bunim |work=ucsf.edu |date=26 September 2013 |accessdate=1 October 2013}} *{{cite web |url= https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/10/should-i-be-getting-health-information-from-wikipedia/280138/ |title=Should I Be Getting Health Information From Wikipedia? – Julie Beck – The Atlantic |first=Julie |last=Beck |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=1 October 2013 |accessdate=2 October 2013}}</ref>
A collaboration between [[Cochrane (organisation)|Cochrane]] and Wikipedia provides access to the [[Cochrane Library]] for the purposes of incorporating their review information into Wikipedia articles.<ref name="Matheson2017">{{cite journal|last1=Matheson|first1=David|last2=Matheson-Monnet|first2=Catherine|title=Wikipedia as Informal Self-Education for Clinical Decision-Making in Medical Practice|journal=Open Medicine Journal|date=30 September 2017|volume=04|issue=Suppl-1, M2|pages=15–25|doi=10.2174/1874220301704010015|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320188268|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Education|Health|Medicine}} *[[Health information on the Internet]] *[[List of medical wikis]] *[[Reliability of Wikipedia#Science and medicine|Reliability of Wikipedia]] *[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Medicine/Research publications|WikiProject Medicine's Research list]], A list maintained within Wikipedia of all academic publications on Wikipedia's health content
